content.heading: HTML - The Head Element
paragraphs: The HTML <head> element is a container for elements like <title>, <style>, <meta>, <link>, <script>, and <base>.

content.heading: The HTML <head> Element
paragraphs: The <head> element contains metadata about the HTML document. This metadata is not displayed on the page but is used by browsers and search engines.

content.heading: The HTML <title> Element
paragraphs: The <title> element defines the title of the document, which is shown in the browser's title bar or tab. It is a required element and important for search engine optimization (SEO).

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
<!DOCTYPE html> 
<html>
<head>
 <title>A Meaningful Page Title</title> 
</head>
 <body> The content of the document......
 </body>
 </html>

content.heading: The HTML <style> Element
paragraphs: The <style> element is used to define style information for a single HTML page.

content.heading: Example
paragraphs:
<style>
 body {background-color: powderblue;}
 h1 {color: red;}
 p {color: blue;} 
</style>

content.heading: The HTML <link> Element
paragraphs: The <link> element defines the relationship between the current document and an external resource, most commonly used to link to external style sheets.

content.heading: The HTML <meta> Element
paragraphs: The <meta> element is used to specify the character set, page description, keywords, author, and viewport settings.

content.heading: Examples
paragraphs: Define the character set used: <meta charset="UTF-8">
Define keywords for search engines: <meta name="keywords" content="HTML, CSS, JavaScript">
Define a description of your web page: <meta name="description" content="Free Web tutorials">
Define the author of a page: <meta name="author" content="John Doe">

content.heading: Setting The Viewport
paragraphs: The viewport is the user's visible area of a web page. It varies with the device. You should include the following <meta> element in all your web pages: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">.

content.heading: The HTML <script> Element
paragraphs: The <script> element is used to define client-side JavaScripts.

content.heading: The HTML <base> Element
paragraphs: The <base> element specifies the base URL and/or target for all relative URLs in a page. There can only be one <base> element in a document.
